seo.title: Asylia.io – Bitcoin Fortress
seo.description: Asylia.io is a Bitcoin fortress built on multi-signature, giving users full control over their keys while offering a dependable co-signer for critical situations. The Collaborative Partial Custody (CPC) model minimises trust in third parties, fees are voluntary and open source guarantees auditability.

introMessage: “Bitcoin Fortress, where sovereignty meets security. Protect your digital wealth with proven multi-signature technology. Because true ownership means responsibility – today, and for the generations to come.”

wp.title: QUICK OVERVIEW (plain English)
wp.p1: What is multi-signature and why do you need it?
wp.p2: Multi-signature (multi-sig) is a proven security mechanism that distributes control over bitcoins among multiple independent keys. A transaction only executes when authorised by at least M of N keys (M-of-N scheme).
wp.point1: No single key holds enough power. Neither an attacker nor a negligent user can move funds alone.
wp.point2: Key loss ≠ bitcoin loss. You only need M functioning keys.
wp.point3: Flexibility of the model. You can include hardware wallets, family, a lawyer or the Asylia vault in the signing process.
wp.point4: Customisable permissions. Define how many keys and which combination is required—2-of-3, 3-of-5, 5-of-7…
wp.q2: Unlocking a bitcoin wallet requires more keys than any single party possesses alone.

p1.title: Private key / seed:
p1.p1: The secret code that generates and secures your wallet.
p1.p2: Never share it and store it offline (paper, safe, vault).

p2.title: Multi-signature (multi-sig)
p2.p1: An M-of-N rule is set. E.g., 2-of-3 signatures → any two of three keys are required to spend.
p2.p2: Losing one key doesn’t cost you bitcoins; an attacker with a single key can’t spend them.

p3.title: Asylia as co-signer
p3.p1: The platform holds only a backup key and never the majority.
p3.p2: Without your signature, funds won’t move, but in a crisis we help finalise the transaction.

visual.title: Visual representation of multi-sig
visual.p: For clarity, we’ve prepared a visual of a multi-sig wallet. Imagine our BTC wallet as a chest (with treasure/bitcoins). There are multiple ways to open it, and even through one opening you can access all contents.
visual.b1: Traditional secure wallets as most people know them.
visual.b4: Multi-signature security. Requires at least 2 keys (of 3) to open.
visual.b5: Multi-signature security. Requires at least 3 keys (of 5) to open.
visual.q2: More keys = less risk of loss or theft. Your bitcoins stay in your hands; Asylia is just an insurance policy.

wp1.title: 1. Introduction: Why a fortress for Bitcoin?
wp1.p1: Phishing, malware, coercion, regulatory pressure and, above all, human error threaten sovereignty over private keys. Multi-signature has historically shown that distributing power among independent parties eliminates a single point of failure and handles unforeseen scenarios (lost key or passphrase, kidnapping, extortion, death, inheritance). Asylia draws inspiration from medieval fortresses—sturdy walls, clear rules and minimal blind trust.

wp2.title: 2. Why Asylia.io?
wp2.p1: Etymology: Asylia (Greek ἄσυλος) = “sanctuary beyond reach”. Symbolises a place immune to unauthorised intervention. The .io domain alludes to input/output and emphasises reliable, continuous access to your bitcoins.

list1.title: We believe in:
list1.p1: Sovereignty and self-sufficiency – keys belong to the user.
list1.p3: Interoperability – respecting open Bitcoin standards (BIP-32/39/43/48, PSBT/BIP-174, Descriptors).
list1.p5: Integrity – doing the right thing, even when no one’s watching.

list2.title: We will never allow:
list2.p2: Speed at the expense of quality.
list2.p3: Centralised control or invasion of privacy.

list3.title: Our promises
list3.p1: Independence – free migration to another platform; keys and bitcoins are yours.
list3.p2: Security – no compromises; auditable code, verified hardware modules.
list3.p3: Transparency – open processes, public roadmap, prompt disclosure of issues.

list1.title: 4.1 Types of multi-sig wallets

p1.title: Backup:
p1.p2: Recovery if one user key is lost.

p2.title: Collaborative signature:
p2.p1: 2-of-3 or 3-of-5, keys split among multiple co-signers (family, lawyer, Asylia).

p3.title: Advanced multi-sig:
p3.p2: Experienced users with bespoke threat models.

list1.p: Best practice: 2-of-3 for personal use or 3-of-5 for significant sums. Asylia never holds the quorum—funds cannot move without your participation.

list2.title: 4.2 Keys & hardware
list2.point_1: Supported HW wallets in MVP: Trezor, Ledger.
list2.point_2: Asylia’s internal keys: 2-of-3 multi-sig, each key Shamir’s Secret Sharing backed and stored in offline HSM vaults.

list3.title: 4.3 Transaction flow
list3.point_2: Signature data transfer via platform, QR code, NFC and more.
list3.point_3: Final transaction broadcast by a public Bitcoin node.

p1.title: No-KYC recovery:
p1.p2: Social recovery & time locks (CLTV/CSV) – planned release.
p1.p3: Optional KYC recovery – future enterprise edition; no-KYC remains available.

list5.title: 4.5 Technical stack
list5.p1: Platform wallet: serverless backend on Supabase (Postgres + Edge Functions / Node.js).
list5.p2: Self-custody mode: no central backend; data stored only in encrypted browser localStorage.

wp5.title: 5. Who is Asylia.io for?
wp5.point1: Long-term hodlers and responsible asset stewards.
wp5.point3: Families, businesses and trusts requiring collective signing.
wp5.point4: Anyone seeking uncompromising protection for heirloom assets.

wp6.title: 6. Business model & fees
wp6.p1: Asylia.io operates with no upfront or ongoing monthly fees. Users may voluntarily include a tip in the transaction as a Bitcoin output.

row2.td2: 2.1 % of the spent amount (charged only when platform key used)

legal.title: Legal framework
legal.point1: MiCA: Asylia is a non-custodial software provider and not subject to CASP registration.
legal.point2: GDPR: IP logs and timestamps retained for 30 days, pseudonymised.

wp7.title: 7. Threat modelling
wp7.point1: Quorum compromise → multi-sig prevents unilateral loss.
wp7.point2: Insider threat → open-source, HSM, code reviews, asymmetric signing protocols.
wp7.point3: Supply-chain attack on HW wallet → hash verification, recommended official firmware.
wp7.point4: Social engineering & phishing → FIDO2/U2F login, educational content, independent confirmation channels.
wp7.point5: Infrastructure outage → offline PSBT, IPFS mirror, migration options to other clients.
wp7.point6: Regulatory pressure → primarily non-custodial SW (MiCA § 4), optional KYC recovery.

wp8.title: 8. Community & collaboration
wp8.point1: Developers & code reviewers – pull requests welcome.
wp8.point2: BTC & multi-sig experts – BIP standard consultations.
wp8.point4: UX beta testers – iterative client improvements.
wp8.point5: Sponsors supporting a secure Bitcoin ecosystem.

wp9.title: 9. Disclaimer
wp9.p1: Asylia.io provides software “as is”. Users bear full responsibility for private key management and legal compliance. Nothing here constitutes legal, tax or investment advice.
wp9.p2: Legal context: Asylia is a non-custodial software provider. Under MiCA, not subject to CASP registration.

wp10.title: 10. Conclusion: The future is secure
wp10.p1: Fortresses of old stood for centuries thanks to strong walls and honourable builders. Asylia adapts this traditional philosophy for the digital age – security, sovereignty and preparedness for generations to come.
wp10.q1:
“Fiat castrum securitatis, et portae fluctuum non praevalebunt.”
(Let the fortress of security stand, and the gates of storms shall not prevail.)
wp10.q2: “Asylia is not here to grow fast. Asylia is here to endure.”

multisig_schema.title: Multi-sig scheme
multisig_schema.p: Backup, co-sig and multi-sig are effectively the same, adhering to the Bitcoin multi-sig standard. The only difference is how they’re used in your wallet.

team.title: Our team
team.q1: “Opus tam validum est quam artifices eius.” – A work is only as strong as its creators.

member1.p2: Asylia.io is not a marketing experiment but a long-term commitment to building a more secure Bitcoin ecosystem, grounded in honour, traditional values and technical precision.
